items.abstract:
<jats:p>Let <jats:italic>w</jats:italic>
               <jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>w</jats:italic>
               <jats:sub>12</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>w</jats:italic>
               <jats:sub>2</jats:sub> be the fitnesses of genotypes <jats:italic>A</jats:italic>
               <jats:sub>1</jats:sub>
               <jats:italic>A</jats:italic>
               <jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>A</jats:italic>
               <jats:sub>1</jats:sub>
               <jats:italic>A</jats:italic>
               <jats:sub>2</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>A</jats:italic>
               <jats:sub>2</jats:sub>
               <jats:italic>A</jats:italic>
               <jats:sub>2</jats:sub> in an infinite diploid population, and let <jats:italic>p<jats:sub>n</jats:sub>
               </jats:italic> be the <jats:italic>A</jats:italic>
               <jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, gene frequency in the <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>th generation. If fitness varies independently from generation to generation, then <jats:italic>p<jats:sub>n</jats:sub>
               </jats:italic> is a Markov process with a continuum of states. If <jats:italic>E</jats:italic>[In(<jats:italic>w<jats:sub>i</jats:sub>
               </jats:italic>/<jats:italic>w</jats:italic>
               <jats:sub>12</jats:sub>)] &lt; 0 for <jats:italic>i</jats:italic> = 1, 2, then there is a unique stationary probability, and the distribution of <jats:italic>p<jats:sub>n</jats:sub>
               </jats:italic> converges to it as <jats:italic>n</jats:italic> → ∞.</jats:p>
title: An ergodic theorem for evolution in a random environment

items.abstract:
<jats:p>Let {<jats:italic>X<jats:sub>N</jats:sub>
               </jats:italic>(<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>), <jats:italic>t</jats:italic> ≧ 0}, <jats:italic>N</jats:italic> = 1, 2, … be a sequence of continuous-parameter Markov processes, and let <jats:italic>T<jats:sub>N</jats:sub>
               </jats:italic>(<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>)<jats:italic>f</jats:italic>(<jats:italic>x</jats:italic>) = <jats:italic>E<jats:sub>x</jats:sub>
               </jats:italic>[<jats:italic>f</jats:italic>(<jats:italic>X<jats:sub>N</jats:sub>
               </jats:italic>(<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>))]<jats:italic>.</jats:italic> Suppose that lim<jats:sub>N→<jats:italic>∞</jats:italic>
               </jats:sub> 
               <jats:italic>T</jats:italic>
               <jats:sub>
                  <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>
               </jats:sub>(<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>)<jats:italic>f</jats:italic>(<jats:italic>x</jats:italic>)<jats:italic>= T</jats:italic>(<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>)<jats:italic>f</jats:italic>(<jats:italic>x</jats:italic>)<jats:italic>,</jats:italic> and that convergence is uniform over <jats:italic>x</jats:italic> and over <jats:italic>t</jats:italic> ∈ [0, <jats:italic>K</jats:italic>] for all <jats:italic>K</jats:italic> &lt; ∞. When is convergence uniform over <jats:italic>t</jats:italic> ∈ [0, ∞)? Questions of this type are considered under the auxiliary condition that <jats:italic>T</jats:italic>(<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>)<jats:italic>f</jats:italic>(<jats:italic>x</jats:italic>) converges uniformly over <jats:italic>x</jats:italic> as <jats:italic>t</jats:italic> → ∞. A criterion for such ergodicity is given for semigroups <jats:italic>T</jats:italic>(<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>) associated with one-dimensional diffusions. The theory is illustrated by applications to genetic models.</jats:p>
title: Ergodicity of diffusion and temporal uniformity of diffusion approximation

items.abstract:
<jats:p>For every <jats:italic>N</jats:italic> ≧ 1, let <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mime-subtype="gif" xlink:href="S0001867800040799_inline1" xlink:type="simple" /> be a real-valued stationary process, and let <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mime-subtype="gif" xlink:href="S0001867800040799_inline2" xlink:type="simple" />. Suppose that <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mime-subtype="gif" xlink:href="S0001867800040799_inline3" xlink:type="simple" /> and var, where <jats:italic>∊<jats:sup>N</jats:sup>
               </jats:italic> and <jats:italic>τ<jats:sup>N</jats:sup>
               </jats:italic> are positive null sequences. Limiting distributions of <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mime-subtype="gif" xlink:href="S0001867800040799_inline4" xlink:type="simple" /> as <jats:italic>N</jats:italic> → <jats:italic>∞</jats:italic> are obtained for the cases <jats:italic>τ<jats:sup>N</jats:sup>
               </jats:italic> = <jats:italic>∊<jats:sup>N</jats:sup>
               </jats:italic> and <jats:italic>τ<jats:sup>N</jats:sup>
               </jats:italic> = <jats:italic>o</jats:italic>(<jats:italic>∊<jats:sup>N</jats:sup>
               </jats:italic>). These results are established by an extension of a method due to Moran. The theory is illustrated by a variety of applications to genetic models.</jats:p>
title: Limit theorems for stationary distributions
